contentrichtext.text: '''Kittanning Gap''' is a gap at the summit of [[Allegheny Ridge]]{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} in central [[Pennsylvania]] in the [[United States]]. It is located in [[Logan Township, Blair County, Pennsylvania|Logan Township]], approximately 5 mi (8 km) west of [[Altoona, Pennsylvania|Altoona]]. ==History== In the 18th century the [[Kittanning Path]] passed through the gap, providing a route between central and western Pennsylvania for [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] and early white settlers. It was later selected as the site for a [[railroad]] line across the [[Allegheny Mountains]]. The challenge of constructing a railroad through the ridge led to the construction of the unique [[Horseshoe Curve (Pennsylvania)|Horseshoe Curve]] in 1854, now designated as a [[National Historic Landmark]]. {{coord|40|29|54|N|78|27|03|W|display=title}} [[Category:Landforms of Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Geography of Blair County, Pennsylvania]] {{BlairPA-geo-stub}}
